ticket.title: :allow_nil option for delegate
ticket.original-body:
Adds :allow_nil option to delegate method:
@@@ ruby # If the object in which you delegate can be nil, you may want to use the # :allow_nil option. In that case, it returns nil instead of raising a # NoMethodError exception: # # class Foo # attr_accessor :bar # def initialize(bar = nil) # @bar = bar # end # delegate :zoo, :to => :bar # end # # Foo.new.zoo # raises NoMethodError exception (you called nil.zoo) # # class Foo # attr_accessor :bar # def initialize(bar = nil) # @bar = bar # end # delegate :zoo, :to => :bar, :allow_nil => true # end # # Foo.new.zoo # returns nil # @@@
ticket.latest-body:
Adds :allow_nil option to delegate method:
@@@ ruby # If the object in which you delegate can be nil, you may want to use the # :allow_nil option. In that case, it returns nil instead of raising a # NoMethodError exception: # # class Foo # attr_accessor :bar # def initialize(bar = nil) # @bar = bar # end # delegate :zoo, :to => :bar # end # # Foo.new.zoo # raises NoMethodError exception (you called nil.zoo) # # class Foo # attr_accessor :bar # def initialize(bar = nil) # @bar = bar # end # delegate :zoo, :to => :bar, :allow_nil => true # end # # Foo.new.zoo # returns nil # @@@
ticket.original-body-html:
Adds :allow_nil option to delegate method:


  # If the object in which you delegate can be nil, you may want to use the
  # :allow_nil option. In that case, it returns nil instead of raising a
  # NoMethodError exception:
  #
  #  class Foo
  #    attr_accessor :bar
  #    def initialize(bar = nil)
  #      @bar = bar
  #    end
  #    delegate :zoo, :to => :bar
  #  end
  #
  #  Foo.new.zoo   # raises NoMethodError exception (you called nil.zoo)
  #
  #  class Foo
  #    attr_accessor :bar
  #    def initialize(bar = nil)
  #      @bar = bar
  #    end
  #    delegate :zoo, :to => :bar, :allow_nil => true
  #  end
  #
  #  Foo.new.zoo   # returns nil
  #

version.body:
Adds :allow_nil option to delegate method:
@@@ ruby # If the object in which you delegate can be nil, you may want to use the # :allow_nil option. In that case, it returns nil instead of raising a # NoMethodError exception: # # class Foo # attr_accessor :bar # def initialize(bar = nil) # @bar = bar # end # delegate :zoo, :to => :bar # end # # Foo.new.zoo # raises NoMethodError exception (you called nil.zoo) # # class Foo # attr_accessor :bar # def initialize(bar = nil) # @bar = bar # end # delegate :zoo, :to => :bar, :allow_nil => true # end # # Foo.new.zoo # returns nil # @@@
version.body-html:
Adds :allow_nil option to delegate method:


  # If the object in which you delegate can be nil, you may want to use the
  # :allow_nil option. In that case, it returns nil instead of raising a
  # NoMethodError exception:
  #
  #  class Foo
  #    attr_accessor :bar
  #    def initialize(bar = nil)
  #      @bar = bar
  #    end
  #    delegate :zoo, :to => :bar
  #  end
  #
  #  Foo.new.zoo   # raises NoMethodError exception (you called nil.zoo)
  #
  #  class Foo
  #    attr_accessor :bar
  #    def initialize(bar = nil)
  #      @bar = bar
  #    end
  #    delegate :zoo, :to => :bar, :allow_nil => true
  #  end
  #
  #  Foo.new.zoo   # returns nil
  #
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body: +1: This seems like a good addition to `delegate`, and I like the simplicity of the implementation.
version.body-html: +1: This seems like a good addition to delegate, and I like the simplicity of the implementation.
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body-html: +1
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body:
+1. Useful, and the patch is very simple.
If anything, I'd change the rdoc to say "If the object *to* which you delegate...".
version.body-html:
1. Useful, and the patch is very simple.

If anything, I'd change the rdoc to say "If the object to which you delegate...".
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body: (Um, that "1." in the comment above was supposed to be a "+1").

version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body:
-1
I dislike silently hiding errors like that. Seems like just asking for trouble.
version.body-html:
-1

I dislike silently hiding errors like that. Seems like just asking for trouble.
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body:
How is it hiding the error any more than:
@@@ ruby def contact_name; contact && contact.name; end @@@
It's intended as a shortcut for the case where not having a contact *isn't* an error. Remember you have to specify :allow_nil, this isn't going to be default behaviour.
version.body-html:
How is it hiding the error any more than:


def contact_name; contact && contact.name; end

It's intended as a shortcut for the case where not having a contact isn't an error. Remember you have to specify :allow_nil, this isn't going to be default behaviour.
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body:
I updated the patch, which no longer applied after the :prefix option was added.
@Josh, as Dave explained, this option is intended only for the cases where this is not an error but a legitimate situation, just to avoid that verbose and ugly definition.
version.body-html:
I updated the patch, which no longer applied after the :prefix option was added.

@Josh, as Dave explained, this option is intended only for the cases where this is not an error but a legitimate situation, just to avoid that verbose and ugly definition.
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body:
I'd like some more attention brought on this ticket (i.e. BUMP), as I've recently found use cases for it abound.
I currently have the following simplified setup:
# A resident may or may not have a current residentship -- he # could be a former resident. class Resident < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :residentships
delegate :room_number, :room, :to => :residentship
def residentship residentships.only_current.first end end
class Residentship < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :resident validates_presence_of :room_number, :moved_out_at named_scope :only_current, ... composed_of :room, :mapping => %w(room_number number) end
class Room # value class, as there's a finite set of rooms def residentship Residentship.only_current.find_by_room_number(@number) end
delegate :resident, :to => :residentships end
I'd like `Room#resident`, `Resident#room` and `Resident#room_number` (as well as several more in my real app) to work properly for former residents, i.e. just return nil -- but with the current implementation of `delegate`, they raise an exception instead. Adding an `:allow_nil` option to `delegate` would greatly reduce the number of extra methods i need to have.
version.body-html:
I'd like some more attention brought on this ticket (i.e. BUMP), as I've recently found use cases for it abound.

I currently have the following simplified setup:

# A resident may or may not have a current residentship -- he
# could be a former resident.
class Resident < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :residentships

  delegate :room_number, :room, :to => :residentship

  def residentship
    residentships.only_current.first
  end
end

class Residentship < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :resident
  validates_presence_of :room_number, :moved_out_at
  named_scope :only_current, ...
  composed_of :room, :mapping => %w(room_number number)
end

class Room # value class, as there's a finite set of rooms
  def residentship
    Residentship.only_current.find_by_room_number(@number)
  end

  delegate :resident, :to => :residentships
end

I'd like Room#resident, Resident#room and Resident#room_number (as well as several more in my real app) to work properly for former residents, i.e. just return nil -- but with the current implementation of delegate, they raise an exception instead. Adding an :allow_nil option to delegate would greatly reduce the number of extra methods i need to have.
version.title: :allow_nil option for delegate

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.

iPad 2 Video Converter Mac is your best choice to convert videos to iPad 2 on Mac OS X.

DVD to iPad 2 is specially designed for Apple users.

DVD to iPad 2 Mac is a wonderful gift for Mac and iPad users

Play 1080P Blu-ray movies with Blu-ray to iPad 2 Converter

Blu-ray to iPad 2 Mac is definitely your best choice to convert Blu-ray DVD to iPad 2 for playback with with its large and high-resolution screen.

Blu-ray to Nintendo 3DS Converter can easily rip/convert Blu-ray DVD, even protected DVDs and encrypted AACS/ BD+ Blu-ray movies to Nintendo 3DS easily and quickly.

DVD to Nintendo 3DS, actally an all-in-one Blu-ray DVD Converter, enables users to convert Blu-ray (.m2ts) ) or DVD movies (.vob) or ISO image files or IFO to Nintendo 3DS/NDSL/ DS, iPhone 4, iPad 2, Motorola Xoom, Android Phones, iPod Touch, Xbox 360, PSP, PS3, Motorola Droid, Nexus One, HTC EVO 4G, etc for entertainment freely.
